Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometer (ICP-MS) System for Elemental Analysis and Speciation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests funds to purchase an inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (ICPMS) system for trace element and speciation analysis. The proposed system offers five key improvements over current equipment at UNM: a) improved detection limits, b) speciation of
metals by HPLC separation, c) spot analysis of solid samples through use of existing laser ablation equipment, d) analysis of biological thin sections using a CryoCell, and e) isotopic analysis. This instrument will be integral to the research and training missions at UNM in areas related to energy development, water resources, and protection of the environment, and human health. Knowledge gained from research conducted at UNM and students graduating from its academic programs will be key to permitting responsible development of energy resources as well as protection of human health and environment in the arid southwest.

MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometer (ICP-MS) System for Elemental Analysis and Speciation,

 Project Outcomes Report

This project involved purchase of an inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) system for trace element and speciation analysis.  The ICP-MS system is coupled with a high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and advanced detectors to provide state-of-the-art detection of trace elements, chemical speciation of elements with multiple oxidation states, and advanced methods for measuring selected organic compounds.  This analytical system has provided support and expanded existing research and teaching in the following areas:

            Energy-Water-Environment research: The arid southwest is a major energy producing region and there is a direct link between energy sources and water resources.  Research on environmental and water impacts of energy development require rapid, sensitive and innovative analyses of solid and aqueous samples.

            Energy production: UNM is leading a large collaborative program to develop electrocatalysts for production of hydrogen gas and oxidation of ethanol in fuel cells.  Trace level analysis and speciation will enable better characterization and understanding of the role of trace elements in catalysis. 

            Environmental engineering: Current research on selective removal of trace contaminants such asarsenic, selenium, and uranium from water will benefit from rapid, quantitative speciation of of these elements by HPLC-ICP-MS.  Speciation of these metals is critical to this research.

 

            Biogeochemistry:  Biogenetic mineral deposits in extreme environments require precision trace element characterization for which ICP-MS will be a significant improvement over ICP-OES.  Supporting microbial culture studies will take advantage of the CryoCell and small-spot capabilities.

            Biological function and toxicology:  UNM has a major research program on the biological function of As and other trace metals focused on their toxicology and interactions with other elements (Zn).  This work will take advantage of high sensitivity for trace level experiments, CryoCell capability for tissue analysis and speciation measurements.

The University of New Mexico contributed to the project by funding renovation of the Geoenvironmental Analytical Laboratory’s (GAL) labs.  This renovation included extensive upgrades to the laboratory’s electrical power system, its HVAC system, and the laboratory’s exhaust system.  Old lab benches were replaced with new equipment and the room was painted.  This renovation constituted part of the required match for the NSF grant in the form of in-kind support.

The major components of the new analytical system consist of:

  • A Perkin-Elmer Nexion 300D inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) system was acquired and installed.  The system has been fully operational since June, 2013.
